bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Bayard T. Horton, December 30, 1940

div1.p: Hench writes that he would like to give his talk on the yellow fever experiments at the University of Virginia. He believes this would help him to raise money for a memorial at Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Bayard T. Horton, December 30, 1940
div1.p:
Remembering your comments on my yellow fever talk, a thought
occurred to me. Some time I should like to give that talk at the University
of Virginia. I have an ulterior motive. As you know, I want to raise a
few hundred dollars, perhaps a few thousand dollars, to erect a suitable
memorial around the site of Camp Lazear. This money will naturally come
from institutions and individuals interested in the work of Lazear, Reed
and others. Since Reed was a Virginia man, I am hoping to eventually call
on the University or individuals of the University for a little financial
help, and I thought that perhaps I might sometime be invited down and give
this talk before the faculty and students, after which I would either pass
the hat or merely make a dignified one-sentence remark to the effect that
any help that any individual or university would wish to give would be most
appreciated. Would you think it proper for you to write, perhaps to the
dean or someone else as if you were writing spontaneously. Tell them
your reactions to my talk and suggest, apparently on your own, that I might
come down there sometime and give it before the faculty and students. There
is one hitch. Moran was there himself just before the W. and J. affair. He
was there only for a morning. He did not see the students or speak to them,
but there was a luncheon given to him by the medical faculty with about 18
or 20 members present, and he spoke for about 45 minutes informally. I don't
believe this would seriously interfere with the interest that my talk might
have for the general faculty of the university, including the medical faculty,
and particularly the medical students who ought to be mighty proud of the work
of Walter Reed.
